element.name: DESCRIPTION
element.text:
Principal component analysis (PCA) is a mathematical procedure that uses an orthogonal transformation to convert a set of observations of possibly correlated variables into a set of values of uncorrelated variables called principal components. The number of principal components is less than or equal to the number of original variables. This transformation is defined in such a way that the first principal component has as high a variance as possible (that is, accounts for as much of the variability in the data as possible), and each succeeding component in turn has the highest variance possible under the constraint that it be orthogonal to (uncorrelated with) the preceding components
In the case of applying this technique to an image with several bands, a new image with a lower number of bands is generated, and redundancy in the data set can be reduced.

element.name: ADDITIONAL_INFO
element.text:
Examples of Principal Components Analysis to land use change detection

* G. F. Byne, P. F. Crapper, and K. K. Mayo. Monitoring land-cover change by principal component analysis of multitemporal landsat data. Remote Sensing of Environment, 10:175–184, 1980.

element.name: NBANDS
element.text: Number of bands of the resulting image. Must be lower or equal to the number of input bands.

element.name: RESULT
element.text: A new raster layer with the specified number of bands. The first one is the band that explains the largest amount of variance.
